advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''PB 700, the extensible personal computer''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FROM WALKMAN TO M5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This US dealer advert says that the designer of the M5, Toshiaki Kamijo was before the Walkman inventor in Sony CIE.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT FS II, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-502 was also called the Diabolik in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR CONVENTION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Altair Convention was here announced in the Computer Notes magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-3100 (FEB. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, working away from your office meant baving to settle for lesser computers or no computer at all.<br> Toshiba ends that compromise. The T3100 delivers the power of an IBM PC AT in a lean, 15-pound computer that you can take with you. With a full-sized keyboard and advanced gas plasma display that give you equal comfort and clarity on your desk or on the road <br><br> Don't let its size fool you.<br> Though the T3100 is no bigger than many laptop computers, it offers the power of a full function IBM compatible desktop AT system. You get the speed and ease of a built-in hard disk, communications and expansion options, and more-including dual-voltage power that lets you plug in and go to work just about anywhere in the world.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Stop everything !''<br> ''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MITS BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our all-in-one BMC IF-800 computer is easier for dealers to sell, customers to buy and OEM to use in their systems...<br> ... You can upgrade to a 16 bit CPU which offers IBM PC compatible MS-DOS and CP/M-86...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>From the magazine 'Micro Sistemas' of March 1983 <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.mci.org.br </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATHKIT CENTERS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The EX3000 Computer, a typical success(?) saga of the early personal computer days.
The Extensis Corp. EX3000 computer pulled together four emerging technologies; multiprocessor supercomputers, 8 bit microprocessors, the S100 bus standard and multiprocessor, multitasking multiuser operating systems.
The hardware of the EX3000 system consists of subsystems and boards. Three subsystems were provided :
FOS100 > Floppy disk subsystem (from one to four MB) MTS100 > Multiple terminal system with 8 or more independant RS232c serial interfaces TPS100 > Terminal / Operator Processor Subsystem with keyboard, CRT, RS232c and expanded video attributes.
And the following boards were included in the EX3000 :
RM64A > Memory board with 16 KB RAM MM16 > Memory Management board with bankswitching up to 1 MB. MPU8085 > 8085 Central processor with onboard PROM MPU800 > Optional Z80 CPU with onboard PROM
The operating system, EMOS, is a multi tasking, multi users operating system which provides memory protection for each user. It can handle the two processors simultaneously. Several languages were developped for this operating system : Extended Basic, Cobol and ANSI Fortran.
computer.name: EX3000
